CatDescriptText: Sidney Johnson, student, Herron Avenue and Helen Hayes, hotel employee, Schenley Heights, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 22, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes, when unable to obtain a 'square deal,' in politics, should register a 'protest' vote by voting for Negro candidates on a ticket, or should they utilize other tactics to protest and continue to vote for all candidates who are qualified and will serve their interests best?" Sidney Johnson's answer reads: "I think we should vote for those qualified, and not soley because a Negro.  Some Negroes are not qualified, and when elected to office they seem to lean over backwards to please the political bosses in order to keep their jobs...Negroes should vote for the candidate who is backed by the mass of Negroes.  That way, they probably will receive fair treatment..."  Helen Hayes' answer reads: "I think we should suport [sic] our race and our won candidates because this gives us a better knowledge by making us stronger."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Sidney Johnson wearing dark hat, moustache, and coat with toggle buttons, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Helen Hayes wearing light colored blouse and dark coat with triangular striped lining, standing in front of Thrift Drugs, corner of Fifth and Liberty Avenues, Downtown
